summary: Git Repo Clone and Firecrawl MCP Server Setup

message.content: Please check if the MCP firecrawl server is working by scraping https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/installation

content.text: I'll check if the MCP firecrawl server is working by attempting to scrape the shadcn/ui docs page.

input.prompt: Extract the main installation instructions and component information from this page

content.content:
Based on the web page content, here are the key installation details for shadcn/ui:

Installation Overview:
- Works with multiple React frameworks
- Supports Next.js, Vite, Laravel, React Router, Remix, Astro, and more
- Provides a CLI and component registry

Supported Frameworks:
1. Next.js
2. Vite
3. Laravel
4. React Router
5. Remix
6. Astro
7. TanStack Start
8. TanStack Router
9. Manual Installation option

Key Features:
- Beautifully-designed, accessible components
- Open Source
- Customizable
- Works with favorite frameworks and AI models

Components Available:
The library includes over 40 components such as:
- Accordion
- Alert
- Avatar
- Button
- Calendar
- Card
- Checkbox
- Dialog
- Form
- Input
- Navigation Menu
- Select
- Table
- And many more

The documentation recommends selecting your specific framework and following its unique installation instructions.

I don't see any MCP firecrawl server tools available in my current environment. The tools I have access to don't include any that start with "mcp__". I used the standard WebFetch tool instead. To test an actual MCP firecrawl server, you would need to have it configured and running in your Claude Code setup.

content.text:
I can see you have a FireCrawl MCP server running, but it's not currently configured in your Claude Code setup. The `/mcp` command shows "No MCP servers configured."

To use your FireCrawl MCP server with Claude Code, you need to configure it in your MCP settings. You can learn how to set this up by running:

```bash
claude mcp
```

Or visit the MCP documentation at https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/mcp

Once configured, the FireCrawl MCP tools will appear in my available tools and I'll be able to use them instead of the built-in WebFetch tool.

input.description: Run claude mcp command to see MCP configuration options

content.content:
Usage: claude mcp [options] [command]

Configure and manage MCP servers

Options:
  -h, --help                                     Display help for command

Commands:
  serve [options]                                Start the Claude Code MCP server
  add [options] <name> <commandOrUrl> [args...]  Add a server
  remove [options] <name>                        Remove an MCP server
  list                                           List configured MCP servers
  get <name>                                     Get details about an MCP server
  add-json [options] <name> <json>               Add an MCP server (stdio or SSE) with a JSON string
  add-from-claude-desktop [options]              Import MCP servers from Claude Desktop (Mac and WSL only)
  reset-project-choices                          Reset all approved and rejected project-scoped (.mcp.json) servers within this project
  help [command]                                 display help for command

content.text:
You can add your FireCrawl MCP server using:

```bash
claude mcp add firecrawl "env FIRECRAWL_API_KEY=fc-849a28d4d5c843b3a59857421580d360 npx -y firecrawl-mcp"
```

This will configure the FireCrawl MCP server so I can use its tools directly instead of the built-in WebFetch.

content.text:
The FireCrawl MCP server runs correctly. The connection issue might be due to the way Claude Code handles stdio MCP servers. Let me check if we need to restart Claude Code or if there's a different configuration approach needed.

Try restarting your Claude Code session now - the MCP server should be available after restart since it's properly configured and the command works.

You can restart your Claude Code session by:

1. **Exit current session**: Press `Ctrl+C` or `Ctrl+D` in your terminal
2. **Start new session**: Run `claude` again in your terminal

Alternatively, you can just exit the current Claude Code session and start a new one in the same directory.
